summary:
•Project Impact: Led impactful projects in engineering, sustainability, and digital transformation, driving process optimization, innovation, and operational efficiency improvements.
•Innovation Leadership: Spearheaded initiatives leading to the improvement of bold and strategic projects, driving innovation across the organization. Direct point of contact to collaborate with the CTO for innovation.
•Digital Transformation: Implemented digital tools and solutions, significantly improving data management, analysis, and overall operational efficiency.
•Client Project Management: Contributed to client project management, ensuring streamlined processes and driving innovation in biomaterial engineering.
•Technology Operations: Led projects that positively impacted technology operations, driving harmonization and innovation across the organization.
•Strategic Leadership: Instrumental in driving project management excellence, establishing best practices, and ensuring the successful delivery of key initiatives across global operations.
headline: Head of Global Operations PMO- Life Science Services- CTDMO

publications.description:
Controlling the self-assembly of multicomponent systems provides
a key to designing new materials and understanding the molecular
complexity of biology. Here, we demonstrate the first use of
MALDI-imaging to characterize a multicomponent self-assembling
peptide fiber. Observations of mixed peptide systems over time
demonstrate how simple sequence variation can change the balance
between kinetic and thermodynamic products.
publications.name: MALDI-imaging enables direct observation of kinetic and thermodynamic products of mixed peptide fiber assembly

publications.description: The self-assembling peptide IKHLSVN, inspired by inspection of a protein-protein interface, has previously been reported as one of a new class of bio-inspired peptides. Here the peptide, dubbed littleSven, and modifications designed to probe the resilience of the sequence to self-assembly, is characterised. Although the parent peptide did not form a hydrogel, small modifications to the sequence (one side chain or an N-terminus modification) led to hydrogels with properties (eg. gelation time and rheology) that could be tuned by these small alterations. The results suggest that peptides derived from protein-protein interfaces are resilient to changes in sequence and can be harnessed to form hydrogels with controlled properties.
publications.name: Controlling gelation with sequence: Towards programmable peptide hydrogels.

publications.description: Antimicrobial proteins are a rich source of new lead compounds for the development of new drugs that will tackle global resistance towards existing antibiotics. Caenopore-5 (Cp-5) is an antimicrobial protein (AMP) expressed in the intestine of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans and is a member of the lipid binding saposin-like-protein family, composed of 5 α-helices and 3 disulfide bonds. Substitution of the 7Cys and 81Cys by two selenocysteine 7U and 81U afforded a selenocysteine analogue [7Sec-81Sec]-Cp-5, which displayed a higher stability (using thermal circular dichroism) compared to the native protein Cp-5. [7Sec-81Sec]-Cp-5 and an N-terminal truncated peptide exhibited cell permeability similar to the wild type Cp-5.
publications.name: Synthesis and activity of a diselenide bond mimetic of the antimicrobial protein caenopore-5

publications.description: The 2014 report from the World Health Organization (WHO) on antimicrobial resistance revealed an alarming rise in antibiotic resistance all around the world. Unlike classical antibiotics, with the exception of a few species, no acquired resistance towards antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) has been reported. Therefore, AMPs represent leads for the development of novel antibiotics. Caenopore-5 is constitutively expressed in the intestine of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans and is a pore-forming AMP. The protein (82 amino acids) was successfully synthesised by using Boc solid-phase peptide synthesis and native chemical ligation. No γ-linked by-product was observed despite the use of a C-terminal Glu-thioester. The folding of the synthetic protein was confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy and circular dichroism and compared with data recorded for recombinant caenopore-5. The permeabilisation activities of the protein and of shortened analogues were evaluated.
publications.name: Chemical Synthesis of A Pore-Forming Antimicrobial Protein, Caenopore-5, by Using Native Chemical Ligation at a Glu-Cys Site

ingestedContentSummary.title: Initiating More Sustainable Practices in Biology - Get Started Now

message.text:
📢 Join our live webinar on "More Sustainable Practices in Biology - Get Started Now"!
Are you ready to make a positive impact on our environment while advancing your biology research? Then mark your calendars for 
April 16th, 2024, at 3pm CET / 9am EST!
Our expert presenters will guide you through practical examples and introduce more sustainable products specifically designed for common biology applications. Here's a sneak peek at what we'll cover: 
🔬 mPAGE® LUX system: Discover a newly launched solution for fast and safe electrophoresis gel preparation. 
🧬 GenElute™ E: Learn about advanced DNA extraction and purification techniques in just 1 spin. 
🌿 Stericup®-E: Explore a sterile filtration system designed to enhance laboratory efficiency. 
🔍 ZooMAb® recombinant antibodies: Versatile tools for various applications, including in vivo studies, WB, IHC, and flow cytometry.
Don't miss this opportunity to contribute to a more sustainable future in biology. Sign up now and save the date!
#Sustainability  #TeamMerck

Join us in breaking barriers with lipid nanoparticle (#LNP) delivery systems. LNPs have emerged as a game-changer in different applications. LNP delivery offers enhanced stability, cellular uptake, and allows for targeted gene expression. With 30+ years of technical experience in LNP delivery we are here to take your drug from preclinical to global markets. Visit our website to find out more. #CTDMO
